div1.p: Fitzhugh Lee Sees the Light at Last

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, October 21, 1900
div1.p: Fitzhugh Lee Sees the Light at Last.

We are glad to find our old and esteem-
ed friend, Gen. Fitzhugh Lee, at last
aligned with us on the yellow fever is-
sue. Up to this time, or until a very re-
cent date, the general has been rather
disposed to accept the proposition that
yellow fever can be suppressed by the
simple agencies of the shovel, the broom,
and a certain fluency in the matter of
carbolic acid.

This hypothesis was set up simulta-
neously with our beneficent occupation of
Cuba. It had the sanction of Gen. Leon-
ard Wood, previously an assistant sur-
geon in the army, and a physician of
acknowledged merit. It had the sanction
of Gen. William Ludlow, one of our most
accomplished engineer officers and an ex-
pert in general sanitation. It had the
approval--at least presumably--of Gov.
Gen. Brooke, which naturally meant
much. Hundreds of thousands of dollars
were expended on feather dusters, sanita-
tive fluids, and syringes of great power
wherewith to disseminate them--to say
nothing of picks, spades, and carts, per-
haps, &c. The summer of 1899 developed
very little yellow fever. Cuba has its ec-
centricities. Then arose the concerted
jubilations of the wiseacres. American
talent, American genius, American liber-
ality of expenditure had scotched the
grisly bugaboo. Gen. Wood announced in
Boston that yellow fever was extinct be-
cause he had, with his little broom and
bucket, eliminated the material upon
which its direful activity depended. We
were told from Havana, on high author-
ity and with equal complacency, the self-
same thing. And now, as it appears, yel-
low fever has ravaged Havana all sum-
mer long, until there is not a block in all
the city which has not entertained the
dreadful visitor. Gen. Fitzhugh Lee is
somewhat late in making his discovery,
but he is right at last, and we congratu-
late him.

The Post has never throughout this yel-
low fever controversy had any purpose
save that of discouraging the idiotic the-
ories upon which so many false hopes of
security were founded. We knew, as the
result of experience and observation cov-
ering more than a quarter of a century,
that neither chemicals nor street sweep-
ers could control the coming and the going
of yellow fever, any more than could the
prayers of preachers or the incantations
of magicians or the rumblings of pagan
oracles. No one knows the cause of yel-
low fever; no one, therefore, can formu-
late its preventive. What we seek; what
we desire above all things in this connec-
tion, is to dispel the foolish superstitions,
the ignorant terrors, and the demoraliz-
ing theories that have been employed to
invest yellow fever with mystery and
gloom. It is a disease that comes and
goes in the districts in which it makes
its habitat. It is not half as dangerous
as typhoid; it is not one-tenth as loath-
some as smallpox; it is a mere gayety
compared with tuberculosis. Its chief and
only menace resides in the fact that at
times it is epidemic and attacks hundreds
on the same day, and, under certain con-
ditions, spreads like wildfire. But it is
easily treated; its danger to the individual
is very slight, and our officials, instead of
proclaiming it as a deadly visitation, and,
alternately, announcing the discovery of a
prophylactic, should accept the views of
those who know all that there is to be
known about it, and stop their pestiferous
and too expensive nonsense.
